docs.abstract: The good, the bad and the ugly effects of media access on children.
docs.lead_paragraph: Young Americans from the ages of 8 to 18 spend more than seven and a half hours a day on average using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device. On top of that, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation study released last week detailing these habits, many children are electronic multitaskers -- surfing the Web, for example, while listening to music or watching TV.
docs.snippet: The good, the bad and the ugly effects of media access on children.

headline.seo: Fast Food for Dieters Has Its Doubters
headline.print_headline: Forget Jenny Craig. Hit the Drive-Thru.
headline.main: Forget Jenny Craig. Hit the Drive-Thru.

docs.lead_paragraph: Taco Bell and other fast-food businesses have jumped on the reduced-calorie bandwagon, but experts have conflicting opinions on whether fast food is a healthy dieting tool.
docs.snippet: Taco Bell and other fast-food businesses have jumped on the reduced-calorie bandwagon, but experts have conflicting opinions on whether fast food is a healthy dieting tool.

headline.main: Lawrence Garfinkel Dies at 88; Fought Smoking

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Garfinkel, a student of statistics who learned epidemiology on the job, worked at the American Cancer Society for 43 years.
docs.snippet: Mr. Garfinkel, a student of statistics who learned epidemiology on the job, worked at the American Cancer Society for 43 years.

headline.main: Mrs. Obama Promises Aid Increase for Military Families

docs.abstract: The first lady talked about increases that President Obama plans to put in his budget.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama announced today that President Obama's 2011 budget will propose $8.8 billion in funding for programs to support military families - a 3 percent increase at a time when Mr. Obama is calling for a freeze in spending on many non-defense domestic programs.
docs.snippet: The first lady talked about increases that President Obama plans to put in his budget.

headline.seo: Seeing Benefits in Moving Recess Ahead of Lunch at School
headline.print_headline: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School
headline.main: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School

docs.lead_paragraph: Sending pupils out to play before eating might make a difference in their health and behavior.
docs.snippet: Sending pupils out to play before eating might make a difference in their health and behavior.

headline.seo: Nation Watches as New York City Leads Attack on Salt Intake
headline.print_headline: After Smoking and Fats, Focus Turns to Salt
headline.main: After Smoking and Fats, Focus Turns to Salt

docs.lead_paragraph: If he can take credit for nothing else, Michael R. Bloomberg can rightfully claim to have launched a national effort to help people live more healthfully.
docs.snippet: If he can take credit for nothing else, Michael R. Bloomberg can rightfully claim to have launched a national effort to help people live more healthfully.

headline.main: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School

docs.abstract: A simple scheduling switch -- moving recess before lunch -- may improve children's eating habits and behavior in school.
docs.lead_paragraph: Can something as simple as the timing of recess make a difference in a child's health and behavior?
docs.snippet: A simple scheduling switch -- moving recess before lunch -- may improve children's eating habits and behavior in school.

headline.main: Making a Healthy Lunch, and Making It a Cause

docs.lead_paragraph: A Bay Area company grows by providing schools with nutritious meals in the fight against childhood obesity.

docs.lead_paragraph: 1/2: Lowering salt consumption by half a teaspoon a day could reduce cases of heart disease, stroke and heart attacks significantly.
